questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of inability to attain an erection during sexual activity for 6 months. He has had an active sexual life in the past. He reports that early morning erections are present every other day. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. His wife recently filed for divorce. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. His only medications are enalapril and metformin. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The underlying cause of this patient's condition is best classified as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hormonal causes of erectile dysfunction, mediated by decreased testosterone production, include hypogonadism, hyperprolactinemia, hyperthyroidism, and hypothyroidism. Patients with hormonal ED typically cannot develop nocturnal or early morning erections.

B) INCORRECT:

Neurogenic causes of erectile dysfunction include stroke, trauma that affects the brain and/or spinal cord, and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson disease), all of which are absent in this middle-aged patient. Patients with neurogenic ED typically cannot develop nocturnal or early morning erections.

C) INCORRECT:

Anatomic abnormalities that can cause erectile dysfunction include Peyronie disease, hypospadias, epispadias, penile cancer, and phimosis. This patient's normal physical examination rules out an anatomical etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

The risk of developing erectile dysfunction increases with age, likely due to the increased incidence of many risk factors and independent causes of ED, including diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular disease, and neurodegenerative disorders. However, erectile dysfunction is not a normal physiologic development with age.

E) INCORRECT:

Many medications, including SSRIs, thiazide diuretics, and beta blockers, can cause erectile dysfunction. However, this patient only takes enalapril (an ACE inhibitor) and metformin, neither of which cause ED.

F) CORRECT:

Psychogenic ED classically manifests with consistent sexual dysfunction that develops acutely, often during a time of increased psychosocial stress (e.g., this patient's impending divorce). Patients often report a previously active sexual life. Unlike organic causes of erectile dysfunction, patients with psychogenic ED can develop spontaneous erections at night or in the early morning, which can be evaluated with nocturnal penile tumescence testing.

Other common stressors that can precipitate psychogenic ED include depression, performance-related anxiety, and trauma from prior experiences.

G) INCORRECT:

Vascular causes of erectile dysfunction include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and smoking. Although this patient has these risk factors, individuals with vascular ED typically cannot develop nocturnal or early morning erections.
questions.hint: This man has erectile dysfunction (ED), which is defined as the consistent inability to attain or sustain an erection during sexual activity. The underlying cause of this patient's ED often manifests with an acute onset, in contrast to other types of ED that develop more insidiously.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-month history of erectile dysfunction. The problem started shortly after he was promoted to a new position in upper management at his company, which also required that he and his wife move to a new city. He states that his relationship with his wife is generally good but, due to his high workload, they have spent less time together lately, and his inability to engage in sexual intercourse has led to mutual frustration. He says that the only times he regularly has full, prolonged erections is when waking up in the morning and at night. He has hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and benign prostate hyperplasia. His medications are atorvastatin, metformin, and tamsulosin. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 5 years ago. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the penis and testes shows no abnormalities. There is no gynecomastia. Rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, nontender prostate with an elastic texture. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastric bypass surgery is one of the treatment modalities for obesity, which is a risk factor for ED. However, bariatric surgery is only recommended for patients with a BMI ≥ 35, patients with a BMI ≥ 30 and type 2 diabetes mellitus, or patients with a BMI of 30–34.9 who do not achieve significant weight loss with nonsurgical methods. Additionally, the presence of nocturnal erections in this patient suggests a nonorganic cause of his ED.

B) INCORRECT:

Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) is used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which this patient has. While some treatment options for BPH (e.g., TURP and 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors) can lead to ED, BPH by itself does not typically cause ED. Moreover, depending on the severity of this patient's BPH, monotherapy with a different drug (e.g., tadalafil) or combination therapy should be tried before considering a surgical intervention such as TURP.

C) INCORRECT:

Testosterone supplementation is used in the treatment of hypogonadism, which can manifest with ED. However, the presence of nocturnal erections in this patient makes hypogonadism highly unlikely. Furthermore, he does not have any other signs of hypogonadism, such as gynecomastia, decreased muscle mass, or loss of body hair.

D) INCORRECT:

Many medications, including antihypertensives (e.g., beta blockers, thiazide diuretics), antidepressants (SSRIs), and antipsychotics, can cause ED. However, atorvastatin does not typically cause ED. Moreover, treatment of cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., hyperlipidemia) should be continued to prevent organic ED.

E) CORRECT:

Despite this patient's risk factors for organic ED (e.g., hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, history of smoking), the presence of regular nocturnal and early-morning erections suggests psychogenic ED, most likely caused by his recent stressors (i.e., moving to a new city and starting a new job). If the patient does not report regular nocturnal erections, nocturnal penile tumescence measurement can be used to establish the diagnosis. Treatment of psychogenic ED includes psychological counseling for stress relief, sensate focus exercises for performance anxiety, and group psychotherapy.
questions.hint: Regular nocturnal erections are a reliable indicator of the etiology of this patient's erectile dysfunction (ED).

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of a 9-month history of progressive difficulty attaining and maintaining an erection during sexual intercourse. He says that his erections are weak, both when he wakes up in the morning and at night. The patient reports that his mood is good overall, but he is upset that his desire for sexual intercourse has decreased since he developed erectile dysfunction. He is in a monogamous relationship with his wife. His inability to engage in sexual intercourse has led to intramarital tension, which is making him feel increasingly anxious and stressed. They have two children who are in college. The patient works as a janitor; every day, he walks 2 miles to work but has to pause intermittently because of pain in his thighs. He has hypertension, peripheral arterial disease, and occasional tension headaches. His medications are enalapril, aspirin, pravastatin, and ibuprofen. He smoked cigarettes for 24 years but quit 3 years ago when his granddaughter was born. He does not drink alcohol. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, bilateral pedal pulses are decreased; hair growth on the lower extremity is sparse. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. Genital examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
48%


Serum



Cholesterol



Total
223 mg/dL


Glucose
128 mg/dL


Hemoglobin A1C

7.3%


Testosterone
normal


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's erectile dysfunction?

choices.text: Recommend vacuum pump and penis ring

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (e.g., tadalafil, sildenafil, vardenafil) are the first-line treatment for organic ED because they are safe, effective, and administered orally. Tadalafil, which has the longest duration of action of all the PDE5 inhibitors, can be administered with a once-daily, fixed-schedule dose (i.e., regardless of when sexual activity is anticipated). In patients with contraindications to PDE5 inhibitors (e.g., concurrent nitrate use for stable angina), other options should be considered based on patient preference (e.g., intracavernosal alprostadil injections, vacuum erectile device, penile prostheses).

In addition to pharmacotherapy, any underlying cause of ED should be treated and risk factors should be addressed. The most important risk factors for organic ED are hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, and smoking, all of which are present in this patient. Since this patient also has bilateral thigh claudication, which suggests aortoiliac occlusive disease (Leriche syndrome), he should undergo additional workup (e.g., Duplex ultrasonography, CT angiography) and be referred for early revascularization procedures.

B) INCORRECT:

Testosterone replacement therapy should be considered in a patient with suspected hypogonadism, which can manifest with ED, decreased libido, and sparse body hair growth, all of which are seen in this patient. However, this patient's testosterone levels are normal, which is inconsistent with hypogonadism; his ED and localized hair loss (in the lower extremities) are most likely attributable to peripheral arterial disease, and his loss of libido is most probably due to the stress and anxiety associated with his sexual dysfunction rather than hypogonadism.

C) INCORRECT:

A vacuum pump (vacuum erectile device) and a penis ring are second-line treatment options for organic ED. Other therapeutic options should be considered first.

D) INCORRECT:

Intracavernous prostaglandin E1 (e.g., alprostadil) injection is a second-line therapy for organic ED. Other therapeutic options should be attempted before proceeding to intracavernous prostaglandin injections.

E) INCORRECT:

Certain antihypertensives, e.g., beta blockers and thiazide diuretics, are known to cause ED. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) typically do not cause ED and can be safely continued in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Psychotherapy is used to treat isolated psychogenic ED, which causes intermittent, situational ED and does not impair early morning or nocturnal erections. Psychotherapy is not the first-line treatment for organic ED. The stress and anxiety associated with his sexual dysfunction would most likely resolve following treatment for organic ED.
questions.hint: This patient has hypertension, peripheral artery disease, and increased total cholesterol, glucose, and HbA1c levels. Given that he has difficulty attaining and maintaining an erection both during sexual intercourse and upon waking up, the cause of his erectile dysfunction (ED) is most likely organic.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old former smoker with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and stable coronary artery disease wants to discuss options for treating erectile dysfunction. He reports progressive inability to maintain an erection for the duration of intercourse. He states that his brother had similar symptoms that are satisfactorily managed with tadalafil, and he would like to try it himself.
The patient’s current medications are insulin glargine, metformin, metoprolol, isosorbide mononitrate, irbesartan, and hydrochlorothiazide.
Which one of the following treatments for this patient’s erectile dysfunction is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as vardenafil, are considered first-line treatment for erectile dysfunction. These medications increase penile cyclic guanosine monophosphate and induce relaxation of penile smooth muscle. In this patient who is taking a nitrate (isosorbide), PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated because severe hypotension can occur. If this patient were not taking isosorbide, his other medications would not be contraindications to use of a PDE-5 inhibitor.

B) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as tadalafil, are considered first-line treatment for erectile dysfunction. These medications increase penile cyclic guanosine monophosphate and induce relaxation of penile smooth muscle. In this patient who is taking a nitrate (isosorbide), PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated because severe hypotension can occur. If this patient were not taking isosorbide, his other medications would not be contraindications to use of a PDE-5 inhibitor.

C) CORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction, defined as the inability to consistently achieve or sustain a penile erection to permit satisfactory sexual intercourse, is a common concern as men age. This patient has several risk factors for erectile dysfunction: type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, a history of cigarette smoking, and antihypertensive medication use. Other risk factors are benign prostatic hyperplasia, hypogonadism and other endocrine disorders, central nervous system disease, spinal cord injury, depression, and marital stress.

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as tadalafil, sildenafil, and vardenafil, are considered first-line treatment for erectile dysfunction. These medications increase penile cyclic guanosine monophosphate and induce relaxation of penile smooth muscle. In this patient who is taking a nitrate (isosorbide), PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated because severe hypotension can occur. If this patient were not taking isosorbide, his other medications would not be contraindications to use of a PDE-5 inhibitor.

Vacuum erection devices and penile prosthetic devices can be used in patients in whom a PDE-5 inhibitor is contraindicated. Vacuum devices, which confer lower risk than penile implants, are the preferred option for managing this patient’s erectile dysfunction. Another acceptable alternative would be intraurethral administration of alprostadil.

Key learning point: Because of the risk for severe hypotension, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor should not be used in men who are already taking a nitrate medication.

D) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is indicated for benign prostatic hyperplasia and for some patients with nephrolithiasis. It has no role in the management of erectile dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Testosterone replacement is not indicated in a patient without documented hypogonadism.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man reports recent-onset erectile dysfunction characterized by diminished libido and difficulty obtaining an erection. He has a history of insulin-treated diabetes and depression, for which he sees a psychiatrist and therapist regularly. Three months ago, he started taking fluoxetine for his depression. He had surgery to repair a left inguinal hernia one year ago.
An affirmative answer to which one of the following questions would be most consistent with hypogonadism as a cause of this patient’s erectile dysfunction?

choices.text: Have you needed to shave less often?
Do you lose your erection during intercourse?
Are you able to generate an erection with masturbation?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with erectile dysfunction due to untreated depression or anxiety often experience spontaneous morning erections.

B) CORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction has multiple possible causes in this case. Diabetes is associated with sexual dysfunction because of damage to nerves and small blood vessels. Depression can cause sexual dysfunction, as can its treatment. Fluoxetine, like all selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors, can reduce libido and impair erectile function. However, this patient could also have primary or secondary hypogonadism.

Diabetes, depression, and antidepressants are not typically associated with changes in secondary sexual characteristics, such as loss of body hair, facial hair, or muscle mass. A patient who responds affirmatively to a question about a reduction in shaving frequency should be evaluated for hypogonadism. It should be noted, however, that although a change in shaving frequency is quite specific to hypogonadism, it is not very sensitive; most men with established facial hair growth do not notice a change in such growth when they develop hypogonadism. Therefore, this patient should likely be evaluated further for hypogonadism with testosterone measurements regardless of his shaving frequency.

Key learning point: Symptoms of male hypogonadism include erectile dysfunction, loss of libido, less facial hair, and loss of muscle mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduced sexual desire can be a feature of either hypogonadism or depression, so a question about desire or libido does not help distinguish the cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with erectile dysfunction due to untreated depression or anxiety are able to generate an erection with masturbation, but they may lose tumescence during intercourse.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with erectile dysfunction due to untreated depression or anxiety are able to generate an erection with masturbation, but they may lose tumescence during intercourse.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents for a routine clinic visit. During the interview, he expresses concern about a decline in his sexual performance during the past year. Both he and his wife have a desire for sex, but he has become unable to achieve erections that are adequate for penetration. He has also noticed reduced morning erections. He and his wife have two healthy children, aged 4 and 8.
He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which he takes lisinopril and atorvastatin. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. He works at a desk job and is generally sedentary. He has gradually gained substantial weight during the past decade.
He has a blood pressure of 115/80 mm Hg and a heart rate of 84 beats per minute. His physical examination is remarkable only for obesity (height: 178 cm, weight: 118 kg, BMI: 37.2). He has normal testicular volume and normal penile shaft morphology.
Routine laboratory test results are normal, including a morning total testosterone level of 346 ng/dL (270–1070).
He requests a prescription for a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, such as sildenafil.
In addition to considering treatment with a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, which one of the following approaches is most appropriate for initial management of this patient’s erectile dysfunction?

choices.text: Refer to a urologist for consideration of alprostadil therapy
Recommend weight loss, smoking cessation, and exercise

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Evaluating for male hypogonadism with a morning total testosterone level is reasonable in patients with ED. However, testosterone therapy should be initiated only if a low testosterone level is found and confirmed on repeat testing. This patient’s total testosterone level was normal; therefore, there is no indication for testosterone treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Alprostadil, which is given by injection into the penis or as an intraurethral suppository, is a reasonable treatment option only after a patient has already attempted lifestyle modifications, adjusted any medications that could be affecting erectile function, and tried a first-line ED treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction (ED) is defined as a persistent inability to attain and maintain an erection sufficient for satisfactory sexual performance. Diagnosis requires a detailed medical and sexual history from the patient and, when available, his sexual partner. Initial management should focus on lifestyle modification, adjustment to any medications that might be inducing the ED, and, if desired, pharmacologic treatment.

In this particular case, the patient has several modifiable lifestyle factors that might be contributing to his ED — obesity, cigarette smoking, and physical inactivity. Positive lifestyle changes (weight loss, smoking cessation, and exercise) have been associated with improvements in sexual function and should be part of this patient's overall management strategy. This patient should also be counseled about ED being a risk marker for underlying cardiovascular disease that might warrant evaluation.

Medications known to contribute to ED include antihypertensives, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and sedatives. Although this patient takes the angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor lisinopril, this drug class is not thought to be an important cause of ED (unlike thiazide diuretics or beta-blockers).

First-line medical therapy for ED consists of an oral phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitor, such as tadalafil, sildenafil, or vardenafil. Many clinicians will choose to initiate this therapy in addition to recommending lifestyle modifications.

Key learning point: Erectile function can be adversely affected by several lifestyle factors including cigarette smoking, obesity, excess calorie intake, excess alcohol intake, excess opioid intake, sedentary lifestyle, interpersonal conflict, and stress.

D) INCORRECT:

Medications known to contribute to ED include antihypertensives, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and sedatives. Statins have not been shown to cause sexual dysfunction; thus, discontinuing this patient's statin is not likely to result in improved erectile function.

E) INCORRECT:

Ruling out depression is an important step when addressing erectile dysfunction. This patient has no clear evidence of depression and is therefore not a candidate for an antidepressant, such as fluoxetine. Notably, many antidepressants, including fluoxetine, may induce sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of a 9-month history of progressive difficulty attaining and maintaining an erection during sexual intercourse with his wife. He says that his erections are weak, both when he wakes up in the morning and at night. The patient reports that his mood is good overall. He has hypertension and peripheral arterial disease. His medications are enalapril and aspirin. On examination, bilateral pedal pulses are decreased; hair growth on the lower extremity is sparse. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. Genital examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a normal testosterone level. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's erectile dysfunction?

choices.text: Recommend vacuum pump and penis ring

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (e.g., tadalafil, sildenafil, vardenafil) are the first-line treatment for organic ED because they are safe, effective, and administered orally. Tadalafil, which has the longest duration of action of all the PDE5 inhibitors, can be administered with a once-daily, fixed-schedule dose (i.e., regardless of when sexual activity is anticipated). In patients with contraindications to PDE5 inhibitors (e.g., concurrent nitrate use for stable angina), other options should be considered based on patient preference (e.g., intracavernosal alprostadil injections, vacuum erectile device, penile prostheses).

In addition to pharmacotherapy, any underlying cause of ED should be treated and risk factors should be addressed. The most important risk factors for organic ED are hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, and smoking, all of which are present in this patient. Since this patient also has bilateral thigh claudication, which suggests aortoiliac occlusive disease (Leriche syndrome), he should undergo additional workup (e.g., Duplex ultrasonography, CT angiography) and be referred for early revascularization procedures.

B) INCORRECT:

A vacuum pump (vacuum erectile device) and a penis ring are second-line treatment options for organic ED. Other therapeutic options should be considered first.

C) INCORRECT:

Intracavernous prostaglandin E1 (e.g., alprostadil) injection is a second-line therapy for organic ED. Other therapeutic options should be attempted before proceeding to intracavernous prostaglandin injections.

D) INCORRECT:

Certain antihypertensives, e.g., beta blockers and thiazide diuretics, are known to cause ED. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) typically do not cause ED and can be safely continued in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Psychotherapy is used to treat isolated psychogenic ED, which causes intermittent, situational ED and does not impair early morning or nocturnal erections. Psychotherapy is not the first-line treatment for organic ED.
questions.hint: This patient has hypertension and peripheral artery disease. Given that he has difficulty attaining and maintaining an erection both during sexual intercourse and upon waking up, the cause of his erectile dysfunction (ED) is most likely organic.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents with a two-month history of difficulty maintaining an erection. He notes it occurs only with his partner and not during masturbation or upon waking. He reports significant stress at work. He has no chronic medical conditions. Physical examination is normal. Basic laboratory tests, including fasting glucose and lipid profile, are within normal limits.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Morning serum testosterone levels assess hypogonadism, but this patient lacks symptoms like diminished libido or reduced energy. His preserved erectile function during masturbation and upon waking suggests intact hormonal status, indicating a psychogenic rather than endocrine cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Penile Doppler ultrasound evaluates vascular causes of erectile dysfunction. This patient’s normal nocturnal and masturbation-induced erections, along with situational difficulties and stress, suggest a psychogenic etiology. The absence of vascular risk factors makes vascular insufficiency unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's ability to maintain erections during masturbation and upon waking suggests intact physiological erectile function, indicating a psychogenic cause. Stress and anxiety can increase sympathetic tone, impairing erection maintenance. Addressing psychological stress through stress management and relaxation techniques can alleviate performance anxiety and restore autonomic balance. This approach is consistent with managing psychogenic erectile dysfunction, focusing on lifestyle modifications and behavioral interventions before pharmacologic treatments.

Key learning point: In cases of situational erectile dysfunction related to stress, the first step in management is to address the psychological factors, such as encouraging relaxation strategies, before considering pharmacological or specialist interventions.

D) INCORRECT:

PDE-5 inhibitors treat organic erectile dysfunction by enhancing vasodilation. However, this patient's situational erectile difficulties, occurring only with his partner, suggest a psychogenic cause. PDE-5 inhibitors do not address psychological factors and may lead to unnecessary side effects.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 9-month history of progressively worsening difficulty attaining and maintaining an erection during sexual intercourse with his wife. He reports that his erections are weak, both in the morning and at night. He states that his mood is generally good. His medical history includes hypertension and peripheral arterial disease. His medications are enalapril and aspirin. On examination, bilateral pedal pulses are decreased and hair growth on the lower extremities is sparse. Cardiopulmonary and genital examinations are normal. Laboratory studies show a normal testosterone level. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of his erectile dysfunction?

choices.text: Recommend vacuum pump and penis ring.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intracavernous prostaglandin E1 (e.g., alprostadil) injection is a second-line therapy for organic ED. Other therapeutic options should be attempted before proceeding to intracavernous prostaglandin injections.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain antihypertensives, e.g., beta blockers and thiazide diuretics, are known to cause ED. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) typically do not cause ED and can be safely continued in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A vacuum pump (vacuum erectile device) and a penis ring are second-line treatment options for organic ED. Other therapeutic options should be considered first.

D) INCORRECT:

Psychotherapy is used to treat isolated psychogenic ED, which causes intermittent, situational ED and does not impair early morning or nocturnal erections. Psychotherapy is not the first-line treatment for organic ED.

E) CORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (e.g., tadalafil, sildenafil, vardenafil) are the first-line treatment for organic ED because they are safe, effective, and administered orally. Tadalafil, which has the longest duration of action of all the PDE5 inhibitors, can be administered with a once-daily, fixed-schedule dose (i.e., regardless of when sexual activity is anticipated). In patients with contraindications to PDE5 inhibitors (e.g., concurrent nitrate use for stable angina), other options should be considered based on patient preference (e.g., intracavernosal alprostadil injections, vacuum erectile device, penile prostheses).

In addition to pharmacotherapy, any underlying cause of ED should be treated and risk factors should be addressed. The most important risk factors for organic ED are hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, and smoking, all of which are present in this patient. Since this patient also has bilateral thigh claudication, which suggests aortoiliac occlusive disease (Leriche syndrome), he should undergo additional workup (e.g., Duplex ultrasonography, CT angiography) and be referred for early revascularization procedures.

Key learning point: Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors, such as tadalafil, are the first-line oral therapy for organic erectile dysfunction unless contraindicated.
questions.hint: This patient has hypertension and peripheral artery disease. Given that he has difficulty attaining and maintaining an erection both during sexual intercourse and upon waking up, the cause of his erectile dysfunction (ED) is most likely organic.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic for a routine visit. He reports difficulty achieving erections sufficient for penetration and has noticed a decrease in morning erections. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily, leads a sedentary lifestyle, and has gained significant weight over the past 10 years. Routine laboratory tests, including a morning total testosterone level of 12.0 nmol/L (6.1–27.1), are normal. He asks about a prescription for a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, such as sildenafil. In addition to considering a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, which one of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach for his erectile dysfunction?

choices.text: Refer to a urologist for consideration of alprostadil therapy.
Recommend weight loss, smoking cessation, and exercise.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ruling out depression is an important step when addressing erectile dysfunction. This patient has no clear evidence of depression and is therefore not a candidate for an antidepressant, such as fluoxetine. Notably, many antidepressants, including fluoxetine, may induce sexual dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Alprostadil, which is given by injection into the penis or as an intraurethral suppository, is a reasonable treatment option only after a patient has already attempted lifestyle modifications, adjusted any medications that could be affecting erectile function, and tried a first-line ED treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction (ED) is defined as a persistent inability to attain and maintain an erection sufficient for satisfactory sexual performance. Diagnosis requires a detailed medical and sexual history from the patient and, when available, his sexual partner. Initial management should focus on lifestyle modification, adjustment to any medications that might be inducing the ED, and, if desired, pharmacologic treatment. First-line medical therapy for ED consists of an oral phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitor, such as tadalafil, sildenafil, or vardenafil. Many clinicians will choose to initiate this therapy in addition to recommending lifestyle modifications.

Key learning point: Erectile function can be adversely affected by several lifestyle factors including cigarette smoking, obesity, excess calorie intake, excess alcohol intake, excess opioid intake, sedentary lifestyle, interpersonal conflict, and stress.

D) INCORRECT:

Medications known to contribute to ED include antihypertensives, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and sedatives. Statins have not been shown to cause sexual dysfunction; thus, discontinuing this patient's statin is not likely to result in improved erectile function.

E) INCORRECT:

Evaluating for male hypogonadism with a morning total testosterone level is reasonable in patients with ED. However, testosterone therapy should be initiated only if a low testosterone level is found and confirmed on repeat testing. This patient’s total testosterone level was normal; therefore, there is no indication for testosterone treatment.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of a 6-month history of difficulty attaining an erection during sexual activity. He previously had an active sexual life. He reports that he continues to have early morning erections every other day. His medical history includes hypertension and diabetes mellitus. His wife recently filed for divorce. He has a 25-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His current medications are enalapril and metformin. Physical examination is normal. The underlying cause of his condition is best classified as which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurogenic causes of erectile dysfunction include stroke, trauma that affects the brain and/or spinal cord, and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson disease), all of which are absent in this middle-aged patient. Patients with neurogenic ED typically cannot develop nocturnal or early morning erections.

B) INCORRECT:

Vascular causes of erectile dysfunction include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and smoking. Although this patient has these risk factors, individuals with vascular ED typically cannot develop nocturnal or early morning erections.

C) INCORRECT:

The risk of developing erectile dysfunction increases with age, likely due to the increased incidence of many risk factors and independent causes of ED, including diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular disease, and neurodegenerative disorders. However, erectile dysfunction is not a normal physiologic development with age.

D) INCORRECT:

Hormonal causes of erectile dysfunction, mediated by decreased testosterone production, include hypogonadism, hyperprolactinemia, hyperthyroidism, and hypothyroidism. Patients with hormonal ED typically cannot develop nocturnal or early morning erections.

E) CORRECT:

Psychogenic ED classically manifests with consistent sexual dysfunction that develops acutely, often during a time of increased psychosocial stress (e.g., this patient's impending divorce). Patients often report a previously active sexual life. Unlike organic causes of erectile dysfunction, patients with psychogenic ED can develop spontaneous erections at night or in the early morning, which can be evaluated with nocturnal penile tumescence testing.

Other common stressors that can precipitate psychogenic ED include depression, performance-related anxiety, and trauma from prior experiences.

Key learning point: Psychogenic erectile dysfunction is suggested by preserved nocturnal or early morning erections and onset during periods of psychosocial stress.
questions.hint: This man has erectile dysfunction (ED), which is defined as the consistent inability to attain or sustain an erection during sexual activity. The underlying cause of this patient's ED often manifests with an acute onset, in contrast to other types of ED that develop more insidiously.

questions.text: You are seeing a 71-year-old man, a former smoker, with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and stable coronary artery disease. He wants to discuss options for treating erectile dysfunction. He reports a progressive inability to maintain an erection for the duration of intercourse. He mentions that his brother had similar symptoms that were satisfactorily managed with tadalafil, and he would like to try it as well. His current medications are insulin glargine, metformin, metoprolol, isosorbide mononitrate, irbesartan, and hydrochlorothiazide. Which one of the following treatments for his erectile dysfunction is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as tadalafil, are considered first-line treatment for erectile dysfunction. These medications increase penile cyclic guanosine monophosphate and induce relaxation of penile smooth muscle. In this patient who is taking a nitrate (isosorbide), PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated because severe hypotension can occur. If this patient were not taking isosorbide, his other medications would not be contraindications to use of a PDE-5 inhibitor.

B) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is indicated for benign prostatic hyperplasia and for some patients with nephrolithiasis. It has no role in the management of erectile dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Testosterone replacement is not indicated in a patient without documented hypogonadism.

D) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as vardenafil, are considered first-line treatment for erectile dysfunction. These medications increase penile cyclic guanosine monophosphate and induce relaxation of penile smooth muscle. In this patient who is taking a nitrate (isosorbide), PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated because severe hypotension can occur. If this patient were not taking isosorbide, his other medications would not be contraindications to use of a PDE-5 inhibitor.

E) CORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction, defined as the inability to consistently achieve or sustain a penile erection to permit satisfactory sexual intercourse, is a common concern as men age. This patient has several risk factors for erectile dysfunction: type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, a history of cigarette smoking, and antihypertensive medication use. Other risk factors are benign prostatic hyperplasia, hypogonadism and other endocrine disorders, central nervous system disease, spinal cord injury, depression, and marital stress. If this patient were not taking isosorbide, his other medications would not be contraindications to use of a PDE-5 inhibitor.

Vacuum erection devices and penile prosthetic devices can be used in patients in whom a PDE-5 inhibitor is contraindicated. Vacuum devices, which confer lower risk than penile implants, are the preferred option for managing this patient’s erectile dysfunction. Another acceptable alternative would be intraurethral administration of alprostadil.

Key learning point: Because of the risk for severe hypotension, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor should not be used in men who are already taking a nitrate medication.
questions.hint: In this patient who is taking a nitrate (isosorbide), PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated because severe hypotension can occur.
